canonical_explanation.text: Certain natural phenomena like lightning and earthquakes are caused by forces within nature. Lightning is caused by the accumulation of electric charges in clouds. When some objects are rubbed against each other, they become charged — this is called charging by rubbing (friction). There are two types of charges: positive and negative. Like charges repel and unlike charges attract. An electroscope can detect the presence of charge on a body. Lightning occurs when massive electric charges discharge between clouds or between a cloud and the ground. Lightning conductors protect buildings by providing a safe path for the charge to flow to the ground. Earthquakes are caused by sudden movements deep inside the Earth's crust, measured on the Richter scale using a seismograph.
rules: Objects can be charged by rubbing (friction) — electrons transfer from one to another.
Two types of charges: positive and negative.
Like charges repel each other; unlike charges attract each other.
An electroscope detects charge: leaves diverge when charged.
Lightning: massive electric discharge between clouds or cloud and ground.
Lightning conductor: metal rod on buildings to safely conduct charge to the ground.
Safety during lightning: avoid open areas, tall trees, metal objects, water bodies.
Earthquake: caused by disturbance inside Earth's crust due to tectonic plate movement.
Seismograph measures the intensity of earthquakes; Richter scale rates them.

questions.question_text: When you rub a plastic comb through dry hair, the comb gets:
questions.explanation_correct: When a plastic comb is rubbed through dry hair, electrons transfer from the hair to the comb. This gives the comb a negative charge — it becomes electrically charged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The comb may warm slightly (A) due to friction, but the main effect is acquiring electric charge. It does not become magnetised (B) or heavier (D). The comb becomes electrically charged (C).

questions.question_text: Charging by rubbing occurs because of the transfer of:
questions.explanation_correct: Charging by rubbing occurs because electrons (negatively charged particles) transfer from one object to another. The object that gains electrons becomes negative, and the one that loses electrons becomes positive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protons (A) are tightly bound in the nucleus and do not transfer. Neutrons (B) are neutral and do not affect charge. Whole atoms (D) do not transfer during rubbing. Only electrons (C) transfer during charging by friction.

questions.question_text: An object that gains electrons during rubbing becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: An object that gains electrons acquires extra negative charge, making it negatively charged. Electrons are negatively charged particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gaining electrons adds negative charge, not positive charge (A). The object is no longer neutral (C). It does not become magnetised (D). Gaining electrons makes it negatively charged (B).

questions.question_text: Like charges:

options.text: Have no effect on each other

questions.explanation_correct: Like charges (positive-positive or negative-negative) repel each other. This is a fundamental law of electrostatics — similar charges push away from each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Like charges do not attract (A), have no effect (C), or cancel each other (D). They repel (B) each other — this is a basic rule of electric charges.

questions.question_text: Unlike charges:

options.text: Have no effect on each other

questions.explanation_correct: Unlike charges (positive and negative) attract each other. This is a fundamental law of electrostatics — opposite charges pull toward each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike charges do not repel (A) or have no effect (B). While they can neutralise each other (D), they do not disappear — charge is conserved. Unlike charges attract (C) each other.

questions.question_text: A charged balloon sticks to a wall because:

options.text: Gravity pulls the balloon toward the wall
The charged balloon induces an opposite charge on the wall surface, causing attraction
The balloon is wet and sticks

questions.explanation_correct: When a charged balloon is placed near a wall, it induces opposite charges on the wall's surface. The attraction between the balloon's charge and the induced opposite charge holds the balloon on the wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wall is not magnetic (A). Gravity pulls downward, not toward the wall (B). The balloon is not wet (D). Electrostatic induction (C) creates opposite charges on the wall, attracting the balloon.

questions.question_text: An electroscope is used to:

options.text: Detect the presence of electric charge on a body

questions.explanation_correct: An electroscope is a device used to detect the presence of electric charge on a body. When a charged object touches the metal cap, the leaves of the electroscope diverge due to repulsion of like charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electroscope does not measure temperature (A), weight (C), or create charge (D). It detects the presence of electric charge (B) on objects brought near or in contact with it.

questions.question_text: When a positively charged rod touches the metal cap of an electroscope, its leaves diverge because:

options.text: Both leaves acquire the same type of charge and repel each other

questions.explanation_correct: When a charged rod touches the electroscope, charge transfers to the cap and flows down to the leaves. Both leaves acquire the same type of charge (positive in this case) and repel each other, causing them to diverge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The leaves are not magnetised (A), heavier (C), or pushed by air (D). Both leaves get the same charge (B) and repel each other due to like charges repelling.

questions.question_text: A charged object can attract:

options.text: Both uncharged objects and objects with opposite charge

questions.explanation_correct: A charged object can attract objects with the opposite charge (unlike charges attract) and also uncharged (neutral) objects. It attracts neutral objects by inducing opposite charges on the nearer surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A charged object attracts not just positive (A) or negative (B) charged objects. It can also attract uncharged objects (not only charged, D). It attracts both uncharged objects and oppositely charged objects (C).

questions.question_text: Lightning is caused by:

options.text: Accumulation and discharge of electric charges in clouds

questions.explanation_correct: Lightning occurs when massive electric charges accumulate in clouds due to friction between water droplets, ice crystals, and air. When the charge becomes very large, it discharges as a bolt of lightning between clouds or between cloud and ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While clouds do collide (A) and wind blows (D), these alone don't cause lightning. Rain (C) is a separate phenomenon. Lightning is caused by accumulation and discharge of electric charges (B).

questions.question_text: An object can be charged only by rubbing it with another object.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Objects can be charged by rubbing (friction), by conduction (touching a charged object), and by induction (bringing a charged object near without touching). Rubbing is not the only method.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are multiple methods of charging: rubbing, conduction, and induction. Stating that rubbing is the only method is incorrect.

questions.question_text: A positively charged object and a negatively charged object will attract each other.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Unlike charges attract each other. A positively charged object and a negatively charged object will be attracted toward each other due to the fundamental law of electrostatics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike charges (positive and negative) always attract. This is a fundamental law of electricity.

questions.question_text: It is safe to stand under a tall tree during a thunderstorm.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Standing under a tall tree during a thunderstorm is extremely dangerous. Lightning tends to strike tall objects, and standing under a tree increases the risk of being hit by lightning or injured by falling branches.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Standing under tall trees during thunderstorms is very dangerous because lightning strikes tall objects. You should stay indoors or in a low-lying area away from trees.

questions.question_text: When two objects are rubbed together, ___ transfer from one object to the other, causing them to become charged.
questions.explanation_correct: When objects are rubbed, electrons (negatively charged particles) transfer from one object to another. The object gaining electrons becomes negative, and the one losing electrons becomes positive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electrons'. During charging by friction, only electrons transfer between objects — protons remain fixed in the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Like charges ___ each other, and unlike charges attract each other.
questions.explanation_correct: Like charges repel each other — two positive charges or two negative charges push away from each other. This is a fundamental property of electric charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'repel'. Like charges (same type) push away from each other. Unlike charges (opposite types) attract each other.

questions.question_text: A device installed on buildings to protect them from lightning is called a ___ conductor.
questions.explanation_correct: A lightning conductor is a metal rod installed on top of tall buildings. It provides a safe path for the electric charge from lightning to flow to the ground, protecting the building.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'lightning'. A lightning conductor safely channels the electrical discharge from lightning into the ground.

questions.question_text: A lightning conductor works by:

options.text: Providing a safe path for electric charge to flow to the ground
Reflecting lightning back to the clouds

questions.explanation_correct: A lightning conductor does not stop or absorb lightning. Instead, it provides a low-resistance path for the electric charge to safely flow from the top of the building into the ground through a thick copper wire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lightning conductors don't stop (A), absorb (C), or reflect (D) lightning. They provide a safe path (B) for the charge to reach the ground harmlessly.

questions.question_text: During a thunderstorm, you should NOT:

options.text: Go inside a building or car
Crouch low on the ground if caught outdoors
Stand in an open field and hold an umbrella with a metal tip

questions.explanation_correct: Standing in an open field with a metal umbrella is extremely dangerous during a thunderstorm. You become the tallest object in the area, and the metal umbrella acts as a conductor, making you a target for lightning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Going inside (A), crouching low (B), and unplugging appliances (D) are all safe practices during thunderstorms. Standing in an open field with a metal umbrella (C) is very dangerous.

questions.question_text: Earthquakes are caused by:

options.text: Disturbance deep inside the Earth's crust

questions.explanation_correct: Earthquakes are caused by disturbances deep inside the Earth's crust, primarily due to the movement of tectonic plates. When these plates collide, slide, or separate, the sudden release of energy causes tremors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heavy rainfall (A) and strong winds (B) do not cause earthquakes. While volcanic eruptions (D) can cause tremors, earthquakes are primarily caused by disturbances in the Earth's crust (C) due to tectonic activity.

questions.question_text: The instrument used to record earthquakes is called a:
questions.explanation_correct: A seismograph is the instrument used to detect and record the vibrations caused by earthquakes. It produces a record called a seismogram.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A thermometer (A) measures temperature. A barometer (B) measures atmospheric pressure. An electroscope (D) detects electric charge. A seismograph (C) records earthquake vibrations.

questions.question_text: Earthquakes are measured on the:
questions.explanation_correct: Earthquakes are measured on the Richter scale, which rates the magnitude (energy released) of an earthquake. Higher numbers on the Richter scale indicate stronger earthquakes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Celsius (A) measures temperature. Decibel (C) measures sound intensity. Beaufort (D) measures wind speed. Earthquake intensity is measured on the Richter scale (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a safety measure during an earthquake?

options.text: Run toward the building exit immediately
Take shelter under a sturdy table or doorframe
Use the elevator to go downstairs

questions.explanation_correct: During an earthquake, you should take shelter under a sturdy table or doorframe to protect yourself from falling debris. This is part of the 'Drop, Cover, Hold' response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Running to the exit (A) can be dangerous due to falling objects. Standing near windows (C) is risky as glass can shatter. Using elevators (D) is very dangerous during earthquakes. Taking shelter under a sturdy table (B) is the safest action.

questions.question_text: A glass rod rubbed with silk becomes positively charged because:

options.text: Protons move from silk to glass

questions.explanation_correct: A glass rod becomes positively charged when rubbed with silk because electrons transfer from the glass to the silk. Losing electrons gives the glass an excess of positive charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protons do not transfer between objects (A, D). The glass does not gain electrons (C) — it loses them. By losing electrons to silk (B), the glass becomes positively charged.

questions.question_text: Two balloons are rubbed against hair and then brought near each other. They will:

options.text: Have no effect on each other

questions.explanation_correct: Both balloons acquire the same type of charge (negative) when rubbed against hair. Since like charges repel, the two similarly charged balloons will repel each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The balloons get the same charge from rubbing against hair. They don't attract (A), are not unaffected (C), and don't stick together (D). Like charges repel (B), so the balloons push apart.

questions.question_text: If you bring a charged rod near the metal cap of an uncharged electroscope without touching it, the leaves diverge. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: When a charged rod is brought near (without touching) the electroscope, it induces charges by induction. The charged rod causes charge separation in the electroscope, making the leaves diverge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Friction (A) requires rubbing. Conduction (B) requires touch. This is not discharging (D). Since the rod is brought near without contact, this is charging by induction (C).

questions.question_text: Why is it dangerous to swim or stand in a pool of water during a thunderstorm?

options.text: Water is a good conductor and lightning can travel through it, causing electric shock
Water gets very hot during thunderstorms

questions.explanation_correct: Water is a good conductor of electricity. If lightning strikes water or nearby, the electric current can travel through the water and reach anyone in it, causing severe electric shock or death.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water doesn't become poisonous (A) or very hot (D) during storms. Flooding (C) is a separate concern. The danger is that water conducts electricity (B), and lightning current can travel through it.

questions.question_text: Lightning can occur between two clouds or between a cloud and the Earth.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Lightning can occur between two clouds with opposite charges (cloud-to-cloud lightning) or between a negatively charged cloud and the ground (cloud-to-ground lightning).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lightning can indeed occur both between clouds and between clouds and Earth. Both types are caused by massive charge discharge.

questions.question_text: An earthquake of magnitude 3 on the Richter scale is more destructive than one of magnitude 7.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Higher values on the Richter scale indicate more powerful earthquakes. An earthquake of magnitude 7 is far more destructive than one of magnitude 3. Each unit increase represents about 10 times more ground shaking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Richter scale goes from lower (less intense) to higher (more intense). Magnitude 7 is far more destructive than magnitude 3.

questions.question_text: Both objects involved in charging by rubbing acquire the same type of charge.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. When two objects are rubbed together, one gains electrons (becomes negative) and the other loses electrons (becomes positive). They acquire opposite charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two objects acquire opposite charges — one becomes positive and the other negative. If they had the same charge, that would violate conservation of charge.

questions.question_text: The magnitude of an earthquake is measured on the ___ scale.
questions.explanation_correct: The Richter scale is used to measure the magnitude of earthquakes. Higher values indicate more powerful earthquakes. It is a logarithmic scale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Richter'. The Richter scale was developed by Charles Richter and measures the energy released during an earthquake.

questions.question_text: A device used to detect the presence of electric charge on a body is called an ___.
questions.explanation_correct: An electroscope is a device that detects electric charge. When a charged object is brought near or touches it, the leaves of the electroscope diverge due to like charges repelling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electroscope'. This simple device uses gold or aluminium leaves that spread apart when charge is detected.

questions.question_text: When an ebonite rod is rubbed with fur, the rod becomes negatively charged. What happens to the fur?
questions.explanation_correct: When the ebonite rod gains electrons and becomes negative, the fur loses those electrons and becomes positively charged. The total charge is conserved — what one loses, the other gains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both objects cannot be negative (A) — that would violate charge conservation. The fur does not stay neutral (C) or become magnetised (D). Since the rod gains electrons, the fur loses them and becomes positive (B).

questions.question_text: A charged body can attract a neutral body. This is because:

options.text: The charged body induces opposite charge on the nearer surface of the neutral body
Neutral bodies always attract charged bodies

questions.explanation_correct: A charged body induces an opposite charge on the nearer surface of the neutral body (electrostatic induction). The attraction between the charge and the induced opposite charge is stronger than the repulsion from the same charge on the far side.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutral bodies do have charges, just equal amounts (A). Option C doesn't explain why. Gravity (D) is too weak. The attraction occurs due to electrostatic induction (B) — opposite charges are induced on the near side.

questions.question_text: Which part of a lightning conductor is buried deep in the ground?

options.text: The metal rod at the top
A metal plate connected to the conductor through a thick wire

questions.explanation_correct: A lightning conductor has a metal rod at the top, connected by a thick copper wire to a metal plate buried deep in the ground. This plate ensures the charge from lightning safely dissipates into the earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The metal rod (A) is at the top, not buried. There is no insulating cover (B) or rubber base (D). A metal plate (C) is buried underground to safely discharge the lightning current into the earth.

questions.question_text: The outermost layer of the Earth is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The outermost solid layer of the Earth is called the crust. It is divided into several tectonic plates whose movements cause earthquakes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mantle (A) is below the crust. The core (B) is the innermost layer. The atmosphere (D) is the gaseous envelope. The crust (C) is the outermost solid layer of the Earth.

questions.question_text: The point inside the Earth where an earthquake originates is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The focus (or hypocentre) is the point inside the Earth where the earthquake originates. The point on the surface directly above the focus is called the epicentre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The epicentre (A) is on the surface, not inside the Earth. A fault line (C) is a crack in the crust. A tectonic plate (D) is a section of the crust. The focus (B) is the underground point of origin.

questions.question_text: When the diverged leaves of a charged electroscope come together after touching it with your hand, it means:

options.text: The charge has been transferred to the ground through your body

questions.explanation_correct: When you touch a charged electroscope, the charge flows through your body to the ground (earthing/grounding). The leaves lose their charge, return to neutral, and come back together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The electroscope is not broken (A). The leaves aren't heavier (C). Air pressure doesn't push them (D). Touching provides a path for charge to flow to the ground (B), discharging the electroscope.

questions.question_text: During a thunderstorm, you hear thunder after seeing lightning because:

options.text: Light travels much faster than sound
Sound is produced first but reaches us later
Our ears are slower than our eyes

questions.explanation_correct: Light and sound are produced simultaneously during a lightning strike, but light travels much faster than sound (about 300,000 km/s vs 340 m/s). So we see the flash first and hear the thunder after a delay.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thunder and lightning are produced at the same time, not sequentially (A, C). Our sensory organs aren't the issue (D). The delay is because light travels much faster than sound (B).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a safe practice during an earthquake?

options.text: Drop, cover, and hold on under a sturdy desk
Move away from buildings, trees, and power lines if outdoors
Use the lift (elevator) to evacuate the building quickly
Turn off gas stoves if time permits

questions.explanation_correct: Using the lift (elevator) during an earthquake is extremely dangerous. The elevator could get stuck, cables could snap, or the shaft could be damaged. Always use stairs for evacuation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dropping and covering (A), moving away from buildings outdoors (B), and turning off gas (D) are all safe practices. Using the elevator (C) is dangerous during earthquakes.

questions.question_text: Static electricity is generated during ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Static electricity is generated when two different materials are rubbed together. The friction causes electrons to transfer from one material to the other, creating static electric charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boiling water (A), melting ice (C), and dissolving salt (D) do not generate static electricity. Rubbing two different materials (B) causes electron transfer and generates static charges.

questions.question_text: Two charged objects X and Y attract each other. X is known to be positively charged. The charge on Y is:
questions.explanation_correct: Y could be negatively charged (unlike charges attract) or neutral (charged objects attract neutral objects by induction). Both scenarios explain the attraction with positively charged X.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If Y were positive (A), it would repel X. Y could be negative or neutral, so just negative (B) or just neutral (C) alone is incomplete. The correct answer is either negative or neutral (D).

questions.question_text: Which of the following electrical appliances should you switch off and unplug during a thunderstorm?

options.text: None, it is safe to use all appliances
Television, computer, and other sensitive electronics

questions.explanation_correct: Sensitive electronics like televisions, computers, and similar devices should be unplugged during thunderstorms. A lightning strike can cause power surges that damage these appliances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not safe to keep all appliances running (A). It's not just lights (B) or just the refrigerator (D). Sensitive electronics (C) are most at risk from power surges during lightning.

questions.question_text: Lightning is a massive ___ discharge that occurs between clouds or between clouds and the ground.
questions.explanation_correct: Lightning is a massive electric discharge. Huge amounts of electric charge that accumulate in clouds discharge rapidly, producing the bright flash and loud thunder we observe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electric'. Lightning is caused by the rapid discharge of accumulated electric charges, producing a visible flash and sound.

questions.question_text: The point on the Earth's surface directly above the focus of an earthquake is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The epicentre is the point on the Earth's surface directly above the focus (hypocentre) of an earthquake. It usually experiences the most severe shaking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'epicentre'. The epicentre is on the surface, directly above where the earthquake originated inside the Earth.

questions.question_text: An electroscope has leaves that are diverged. When another charged object is brought near, the leaves diverge more. This means the charge on the object is:

options.text: The same type as the charge on the electroscope
The opposite type to the charge on the electroscope

questions.explanation_correct: If the leaves diverge more, the brought-near object pushes more of the same type of charge toward the leaves. This means the object has the same type of charge as the electroscope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An opposite charge (B) would attract charges away from the leaves, causing them to converge. A neutral object (C) would have little effect. It can be determined (D). Same charge (A) pushes more charge to the leaves, increasing divergence.

questions.question_text: Which type of buildings are most likely to survive an earthquake?

options.text: Buildings made of heavy stone blocks
Earthquake-resistant buildings with flexible structural design

questions.explanation_correct: Earthquake-resistant buildings with flexible structural designs can absorb and dissipate seismic energy, reducing damage. They use reinforced concrete, steel frames, and flexible joints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Very tall buildings (A) and heavy stone buildings (B) can be vulnerable. Single exits (D) are a safety hazard. Earthquake-resistant flexible designs (C) are most likely to survive.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about charging by rubbing?

options.text: Charges are neither created nor destroyed, only transferred
The total charge increases after rubbing

questions.explanation_correct: Charging by rubbing does not create new charges. Electrons transfer from one object to another. The total charge is conserved — the total positive and negative charges remain the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: New charges are not created (A). Only electrons transfer, not positive charges (C). Total charge doesn't increase (D). Charge is conserved — only transferred (B).

questions.question_text: If you are travelling in a car during a thunderstorm, you are relatively safe because:

options.text: The metal body of the car acts as a shield, directing charge around the outside
Cars are too small to be struck

questions.explanation_correct: A car's metal body acts like a Faraday cage. If lightning strikes the car, the electric charge flows around the outside of the metal body and into the ground, protecting the occupants inside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cars have rubber tyres but the safety comes from the metal body (A). Lightning does reach the ground (C). Cars can be struck (D). The metal body (B) conducts charge around the outside, protecting passengers.

questions.question_text: The tremors of an earthquake decrease in intensity as we move farther from the epicentre.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The seismic waves lose energy as they travel outward from the epicentre. Therefore, the shaking and destruction are typically greatest at the epicentre and decrease with distance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Earthquake tremors are strongest at the epicentre and weaken as distance from the epicentre increases, as seismic energy dissipates during travel.

questions.question_text: Which experiment can demonstrate that there are two types of electric charges?

options.text: Rubbing a glass rod with silk and an ebonite rod with fur, then bringing them near each other
Placing a magnet near iron filings

questions.explanation_correct: A glass rod rubbed with silk (positive charge) and an ebonite rod rubbed with fur (negative charge) attract each other, proving two types of charges exist. Two glass rods would repel, showing same-charge repulsion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating (B) and dissolving (C) don't involve charges. Magnets and iron (D) demonstrate magnetism. Rubbing different materials (A) and observing attraction/repulsion proves two types of charges exist.
